body.p: Do oddsmakers believe that teams who play at home will have home field advantage? Specifically, do oddsmakers give higher point spreads when the favored team plays home games as compared to when the favored team plays away games?

Two samples were randomly selected from three complete National Football League seasons (1989, 1990, and 1991). The first sample consisted of 50 games, where the favored team played in a home game, while the second sample consisted of 50 games, where the favored team played in an away game. The oddsmakers’ point spreads (which are the number of points by which the favored team is predicted to beat the weaker team) were then collected.
Analyses were run. The following is the (edited) output for the test:
Which of the following is an appropriate conclusion based on the output?

input.choice: The data provide sufficient evidence reject the H0; thus, we cannot conclude that the mean point spread of home games is higher than that of away games.
The data provide sufficient evidence to reject H0; thus, we can conclude that the mean point spread for home games is higher than that of away games.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Notice that the p-value is greater than 0.05. Therefore, there is not sufficient evidence to reject H0.
Incorrect. While it is correct that the p-value is greater than 0.05 and the null hypothesis therefore is not rejected, your conclusion is wrong.
Correct. Since the p-value is greater than 0.05, we fail to reject the null hypothesis and therefore cannot conclude that the mean point spread of home games is higher than that of away games.
Incorrect. Notice that the p-value is greater than 0.05. Therefore, there is not sufficient evidence to reject H0.

body.p: Do college students who are in a fraternity or sorority attend more parties than college students who are not affiliated with a fraternity or sorority? A statistics class randomly selected 50 students who were in a fraternity or sorority and 50 students who were not affiliated with a fraternity or sorority and asked them to report how many parties they had attended in the past month.
Analyses were run. The following is the (edited) output for the test:
Which of the following is an appropriate conclusion based on the output?

input.choice: The data provide sufficient evidence to reject the H0; thus, we cannot conclude that the mean number of parties attended by fraternity and sorority members is higher than those attended by unaffiliated students.

The data provide sufficient evidence to reject H0; thus, we can conclude that the mean number of parties attended by fraternity and sorority members is higher than those attended by unaffiliated students.

response.feedback: Incorrect. You are correct that the data provides sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis because the p-value was less than 0.05 however, the second part of the statement is incorrect—we actually can conclude that there was a difference because the p-value was less than 0.05 so we reject the null hypothesis.

Incorrect. The p-value is less than 0.05 and, therefore, we have enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis. However, you are correct that we can conclude that there was a difference between the two groups.
Incorrect. The p-value is less than 0.05 and, therefore, we have enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis.
Correct. Since the p-value is less than 0.05, we can reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the fraternity/sorority students attended significantly more parties than unaffiliated students.
